column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0494] As seen in FIG. 27, gaming application implementations 2700 may use both the internet and a GPS.

#Text=In one embodiment, a game is downloaded from a customer database via a game provider, perhaps using their web services and the internet as shown, to a user computer or augmented reality glasses.
#Text=At the same time, the glasses, which also have telecommunication capabilities, receive and send telecommunications and telemetry signals via a cellular tower and a satellite.
#Text=Thus, an on-line gaming system has access to information about the user's location as well as the user's desired gaming activities.
#Text=[0495] Games may take advantage of this knowledge of the location of each player.
#Text=For example, the games may build in features that use the player's location, via a GPS locator or magnetometer locator, to award points for reaching the location.
#Text=The game may also send a message, e.g., display a clue, or a scene or images, when a player reaches a particular location.
#Text=A message, for example, may be to go to a next destination, which is then provided to the player.
#Text=Scenes or images may be provided as part of a struggle or an obstacle which must be overcome, or as an opportunity to earn game points.
#Text=Thus, in one embodiment, augmented reality eyepieces or glasses may use the wearer's location to quicken and enliven computer-based video games.
#Text=[0496] One method of playing augmented reality games is depicted in FIG. 28.
#Text=In this method 2800, a user logs into a website whereby access to a game is permitted.
#Text=The game is selected.
#Text=In one example, the user may join a game, if multiple player games are available and desired; alternatively, the user may create a custom game, perhaps using special roles the user desired.
#Text=The game may be scheduled, and in some instances, players may select a particular time and place for the game, distribute directions to the site where the game will be played, etc.
#Text=Later, the players meet and check into the game, with one or more players using the augmented reality glasses.
#Text=Participants then play the game and if applicable, the game results and any statistics (scores of the players, game times, etc.) may be stored.
#Text=Once the game has begun, the location may change for different players in the game, sending one player to one location and another player or players to a different location.
#Text=The game may then have different scenarios for each player or group of players, based on their GPS or magnetometer-provided locations.
#Text=Each player may also be sent different messages or images based on his or her role, his or her location, or both.
#Text=Of course, each scenario may then lead to other situations, other interactions, directions to other locations, and so forth.
#Text=In one sense, such a game mixes the reality of the player's location with the game in which the player is participating.
#Text=[0497] Games can range from simple games of the type that would be played in a palm of a player's hand, such as small, single player games.
#Text=Alternatively, more complicated, multi-player games may also be played.
#Text=In the former category are games such as SkySiege, AR Drone and Fire Fighter 360.
#Text=In addition, multiplayer games are also easily envisioned.
#Text=Since all players must log into the game, a particular game may be played by friends who log in and specify the other person or persons.
#Text=The location of the players is also available, via GPS or other method.

#Text=Sensors in the augmented reality glasses or in a game controller as described above, such as accelerometers, gyroscopes or even a magnetic compass, may also be used for orientation and game playing.
#Text=An example is AR Invaders, available for iPhone applications from the App Store.
#Text=Other games may be obtained from other vendors and for non-iPhone type systems, such as Layar, of Amsterdam and Paris SA, Paris, France, supplier of AR Drone, AR Flying Ace and AR Pursuit.
#Text=[0498] In embodiments, games may also be in 3D such that the user can experience 3D gaming.
#Text=For example, when playing a 3D game, the user may view a virtual, augmented reality or other environment where the user is able to control his view perspective.
#Text=The user may turn his head to view various aspects of the virtual environment or other environment.
#Text=As such, when the user turns his head or makes other movements, he may view the game environment as if he were actually in such environment.

#Text=For example, the perspective of the user may be such that the user is put `into` a 3D game environment with at least some control over the viewing perspective where the user may be able to move his head and have the view of the game environment change in correspondence to the changed head position.
#Text=Further, the user may be able to `walk into` the game when he physically walks forward, and have the perspective change as the user moves.
#Text=Further, the perspective may also change as the user moves the gazing view of his eyes, and the like.
#Text=Additional image information may be provided, such as at the sides of the user's view that could be accessed by turning the head.
